- page 11

The game ends when 1 of the following
2 conditions has been achieved:

â€º The draw pile runs out

â€º There are no more spaces for cards

threads.title: Has anyone read "A Canticle for Leibowitz"?

posts.author: thecorsetmaker
posts.body:
Frequently when playing Revive I am reminded of this amazing work of post-apocalyptic fiction - A canticle for Leibowitz by Walter M Miller Jr. Granted there is much that is different in the game, but it has many of the themes: rediscovering lost tech, shadowy memories of the past affecting cultural development, etc.

threads.title: Stayinâ€™ Alive â€“ A Review of Revive (and the Campaign) as a Solo Player

posts.author: YogiBearandDelaware
posts.body:
Designers: Helge Meissner, Kristian Amundsen Ã˜stby, Eilif Svensson, Anna Wermlund
Publisher: Aporta Games
Artists: Gjermund Bohne, Martin Mottet, Dan Roff, Jessy TÃ¶pfer

Original post on our blog with pictures: https://yogibearanddelaware.com/

Revive is such a unique, fascinating, thinky board game that doesnâ€™t take too long to play (at least solo) but does showcase some really interesting decision making and strategizing. While not mechanically integrated, the theme is present and relevant, specifically in the campaign story. Itâ€™s just overall a really solid mid-weight, smooth euro.

There is honestly quite a lot going on in this game, so Iâ€™m not going to cover too much in terms of how to play or the nitty gritty of the mechanics. Some will be mentioned in my thoughts, but if youâ€™re interested in a game play overview, this is not the review youâ€™re looking for.

First off, let me just say that the setup for this game is rather lengthy. There are a lot of little bits and pieces including wooden components, tiles, cards, etc. that all require some TLC to get the game going. That said, the componentry is nice, and everything fits well back into the box which is always a positive. The artwork is also gorgeous, especially the image on the back of the board.

The rulebook for this game is fantastic, in my opinion. Not only are the explanations of the game done well, but the order of the rulebook integrates with the flow of the game expertly. That first game, you feel like you can sort of following along with the descriptions and play your first turn(s) simultaneously. The symbol reference pages are also phenomenal; there was not one symbol or tile or card that I came across that wasnâ€™t described in detail.

While I only played it solo, I would be interested in testing it in a multiplayer setting. I feel like a four-player game would be quite lengthy, but the player interaction on the main board would obviously be more intriguing when not playing solo. There are also some tribes that have abilities more well suited to a multiplayer setting that I would like to experiment with.

Before I get into what I really enjoy and appreciate about this game, I do want to point out a few small, potential flaws. I always value the inclusion of player aids and reference cards, but these ones are a little weak. I assume they were trying to keep text on them minimal, which I do like, but I still felt like I needed to reference the rulebook at quite a few stages, especially during hibernation. By personal preference, I also am not a huge fan of the beat your own score system for the solo mode. I actually find the design of the solo mode to be lovely but playing to just try to beat any previous scores/reach a certain level in the score chart is a little irritating. From my limited board game design knowledge, it seems like creating and implementing scenarios and/or achievements for the solo game would be an easy addition. Also, I think partly due to this, the game got rather repetitive for me after eight (ish) plays. Iâ€™d likely feel different if there was variation in player count, but always just trying to maximize points wasnâ€™t super motivating.

Now on to my favorite parts! As most people who have read at least one of our reviews knows, I adore a good campaign, especially when it can be played solo. The unlockable components and content during the campaign for Revive was great. Itâ€™s a five chapter campaign, and after the first game, additional elements, content, and rules get introduced that enhance the game play and strategic nature of the game. I also admire how tense and tight the solo game gets towards the end: with the action cube moving up the track when playing cards and hibernating, itâ€™s tough to balance the action selection and resource management with trying to gain points. I always felt I needed one or two more turns to really optimize my game, but I enjoyed that.

One other addition that I greatly appreciate is that the unique tribes do truly play differently, have their own abilities, and their boards display special technologies (and maybe other powers that could get unlocked during the campaignâ€¦). Each tribe board is also double sided to increase that variation. The back side (the moon side) increases the variety of actions, bonuses, and technologies which are really impressive and overall practical in terms of replayability.

My absolute favorite design choice in this game is the interconnectedness between the tech tracks on the player boards and the actions and goals for the game. Itâ€™s challenging to describe without just explaining the whole game, but even though there are a lot of moving parts, action options, components, etc., everything has its place and ties in or relates to some other important aspect of the game (and maybe even the theme). Itâ€™s truly brilliant and it creates such a satisfying puzzle to try to decipher. Itâ€™s a solid combo-making game where one thing lets you do another thing which leads to two more things.

For me, as Iâ€™ve only played it solo, this game isnâ€™t perfect, but it is a really fun and cleverly designed board game. There are a lot of unique elements, some thematic integration, and just really cool, puzzly game play with neat reliability on other aspects of the game. The ultimate creation? A piece of art that is cohesive, strategically deep, and has a wonderful table presence. What more could you ask for!? Unless, of course, we are talking about the win conditions related to the solo modeâ€¦

posts.body: I really donâ€™t play solo but will add that for those that play solo and multiplayer, the multiplayer is one of my top 20 gamesâ€¦..it is a beautiful game and one that made it to our annual rotation (we have actually got this game to the table about 5 times since the holidays).  This is pretty GM rare for a game for us.

threads.title: Factory effects question

posts.author: Altcore
posts.body:
Hello, I have some questions about factory synergy based on our first game.
First example:


Does the effect of the second factory trigger the effect of the first? In the TTS module, the description of the first factory says that it's an action modifier. The effect of the second factory isn't an action, as I understand.

Second example:

The first and third factories modify actions with R&D and mining. Could these effects apply when we have an Innovation Department bonuses?

I think in both cases the answer should be no, because in both cases the wording says that the effect of factory is an action modifier (action on the main board, not the action from the other effects). But in this case, we should always think about not buying factories with these anti-synergy effects (in opposite to how it usually works in other games).

Best regards.

posts.author: Awakening
posts.body:
The first factory triggers every time you take the R&D action, increase the development track by 1 additional space.
The second factory just gives you 5 money when you build it.
The third factory triggers every time you take the mining action, increase the mining track by 1 additional space and gain 1 steel.

The first and third factory only applies to you taking the corresponding action.

posts.author: Altcore
posts.body: Thank you for the answer. What is about the first example?

posts.author: Awakening
posts.body:
Altcore wrote:

Thank you for the answer. What is about the first example?

Oh, it showed the same image on both for me at first so I didn't realize it was a different case ğŸ™‚

That is a good question. The icon and description indicates that it does not trigger since you didn't use the specified action.
Otherwise it should trigger when a machine is placed on that factory. But I think it should only trigger when the machine building action is used.
If that is not the case then a further clarification is needed and a different icon should be used. I would definitely put this into an FAQ.

posts.author: Altcore
posts.body: Yes, the problem in the first example also applies to many other combinations. Like a factory that produces 3 items and another that has a bonus to produce something in this factory. It's a bit tricky to always think about what factory to buy to not break some synergy in engine (totally opposite how it usually works in many other games where all new cards/tiles have synergy and combos with everything else, but I understand that the combos are not a part of this game idea).

posts.author: Awakening
posts.body:
This is from the rules on page 10.


Immediate. Immediately apply the effect of the Factory after placing it on your Zaibatsu.

Action modifier. Factories can modify the actions. You may only apply a modifier from one Factory per action, even if you have more than one Factory with the same respective modifier.

Special. Some Factories have permanent effects or effects triggered in specific situations. Such Factories have no icon to the left of the effect.

Note: Factory effects are not actions, so those effects cannot be modified by the action modifiers.


So this makes it clear that the factories that have those square icons are Action Modifiers.
And the note states that factories cannot trigger Action Modifiers on other factories.

threads.title: New additions/adding to much?

posts.author: graham671
posts.body: For those who have tried the new version: is the game becoming too 'combotastic'? It seems like the recent changesâ€”such as adding silk as a new resource, introducing factory production bonuses, and adding more bonuses to development and income tracksâ€”might lead to excessive combo chains and loosen up the game a bit.

posts.author: Awakening
posts.body: I would not call this game combotastic. Sometimes you do one thing that triggers one other thing. For example you could buy a factory that raises your development and that could trigger income of 2/3 coal. The number of things that can trigger other things is very limited and they do so very rarely. For example the development track only triggers coal once and then unlocks influence markers 3 times. That's it, and you are not likely to do all that every game.

posts.author: 1ngu
posts.body:
Sorry for this getting long and maybe a bit outside of the scope of your original question, but it all ties in with the new additions to the game.
I'd say it depends on what you compare it to. In comparison to og Nippon, I would argue that one might call this game 'combotastic' or 'abundant', but in comparison to other games; maybe not so much.
l'll just start by saying that I've only played og Nippon a handful of times, all within this year except an old play on BGA a few years back, so I'm in no way an expert.
But I've followed the campaign as I like the game and wanted to see what this new version brought to the table. And I do share a lot of the 'concerns' that's been voiced so far. My two main concerns with the new version was that it's become too 'abundant' in resources and leans more into multiplayer solitaire.

I think Board gaming ramblings did a good comparison in their video, and they addressed the fact that vp multipliers are now on your own board instead of in a common pool, which I am not really a fan of. The race to grab the high multipliers is completely gone and you can consolidate at your own leisure knowing your high scoring tokens are still there waiting for you to decide what to do with them, making you able to play it a bit more safe and not have to chicken race others in grabbing the x5s or x4s.
Also the new department makes me feel like players will focus more on what they need themselves in terms of bonuses, rather than in what colour worker other players are focusing on and what might be 'left alone' for you to consolidate for cheap (or for others to draft just to make it more expensive for you, there's that aspect as well).
When I watched the 2p playthrough from Before you play I felt they had so many resources all the time and albeit tight, some of it felt not so tight anymore. But maybe they're just good at the game or good at resource management in general?

So I tried the solo mode on TTS. I am not at all a fan of TTS so I didn't exactly bring my 'a-game', I just wanted to try it out.
Even so, I had so much coal and steel that getting enough actions to actually spend them became almost like a chore. I took a starting tile that gave me a ship, so I tried to lean into a ship strategy. Also because of the new ship mechanic, to get a good feel for it.
I always felt like I took the ship action 'too late' in a round so I didn't have enough space left for the expert workers. I'm sure if you play the game more you'll figure out how to plan for it, but I almost always had steel to build 2 or 3 ships, but not enough space for the workers.
And to be honest, I'm unsure how to go about building 3 ships in one turn and still have a good foundation for consolidation, since 3 ships will take up 4 of the 6 department slots, leaving only 2 actions to spend all your money and coal before they're discarded in a consolidation. I do realize I might have played thinking like in og Nippon, and upon playing Zaibatsu more I reckon you'd get a better feel for when to take what resources as to not take more resources than you need, but even so the game just 'gives you resources' at times that you then have to do something with (as mentioned above when going up the different tracks etc).

A bit of a side step from your original question, but in a way it ties in with combotasticness and abundance. I had the means (steel) to build 3 ships, but I didn't see the benefit of doing so cause I had so much of my other resources that I also needed to spend before consolidating. And had I used the steel to build trains, the first two in every region gives you more resources.

So for me I'm sticking with my og Nippon. I don't find the new game to be bad per se, if you like to do your own thing (not having to race for scoring multipliers) and like having enough resources to not feel too restricted, then the new version I'd say is still a good game, but for me personally and for the reasons I like Nippon, I feel like the new version is not for me.

posts.author: fabio
posts.body:
Unfortunately, it seems that this rules really leaves too many open questions. I have listed several in other posts as well. From your post, the only one I can answer for sure is the one about mission cards. In fact, on the rules this sentence is present (page 22):

If there is an open space after a Mission card is taken, replace it with a card from the appropriate deck.


The rules do not mention that they must be rearranged in numerical order when adding a new card, however, at the top of the page is indicated:

These cards are divided into 2 decks, and there will always be only 3 cards from each deck on the board. These cards are arranged in numerical order from top to bottom (higher number on top), observing the numbers in the top left corner of the cards.


So I suppose that you have to rearrange the cards every time a new card comes into play. Of this last deduction, however, I am not at all sure.
